Award.AwardTitle: Cognitive characteristics of the leaders of language change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research project is to deepen our understanding of how dialect features spread across social groups. A person's accent often provides clues about their identity, such where they grew up or how old they are. A regional accent can also influence whether a person is perceived as well-educated, friendly, ignorant, or stuck-up, meaning accents have real consequences in people's lives. Linguists have learned a lot about how accent features spread across social groups through cities and regions, eventually turning into new languages entirely. But the questions of how accent changes get started in the first place and then spread from person to person remain unanswered. Whose accent catches on? Who picks up features of other people's speech?

This project looks at several ongoing changes in the Philadelphia accent with the goal of identifying what types of people drive these changes forward. The Philadelphia accent is one of the best-studied accents in the world thanks to research done in the city since the 1970s, allowing for comparison to older forms of the accent. In this project researchers record casual conversations between pairs of Philadelphian friends and conduct acoustic analysis of their speech in order to identify individuals who have particularly innovative Philly accents. The same participants then complete a series of experiments and surveys that provide data about their information processing style, linguistic awareness and flexibility, and personality. These participant traits are then correlated with the speech data in order to test hypotheses about what kinds of people are at the forefront of language change. The results will not only provide a very fine-grained picture of how language changes over time, but also bring new evidence to bear on the feedback loop between the characteristics of the human mind and properties of human social behavior in groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Regional accents arise when a number of different pronunciation changes gradually take place in one region. Understanding how regional accents develop is of interest to linguists because we think it is the same process that leads to the divergence of entire languages over longer timespans, such as the development of French, Spanish, and Italian from their common ancestor, Latin. In the present day, the many different regional accents in the United States can be a source of cultural pride and local identity, but can also lead to discrimination when even subtle pronunciation differences are mistakenly attributed to laziness or stupidity. The many ways in which accents differ from each other also pose a challenge for our rapidly advancing speech recognition technologies. Research on language change can improve our everday technologies, our awareness of the differences that unfairly divide us, and our scientific understanding of language as a uniquely human capacity.

Sociolinguists have studied many different regional accents in the US and given careful attention to the way our social backgrounds and community structures shape the way we speak. Factors such as race, gender, and socioeconomic class have all been shown to influence the use of new pronunciation features. In this study, we asked what makes some individuals more likely than others to adopt linguistic innovations, even when they come from very similar sociodemographic backgrounds. It has been hypothesized that aspects of personality and cognitive processing style are possible predictors of these within-group individual differences in language change.

We recruited 56 young white Philadelphian women of similar ages, socioeconomic backgrounds, and educational levels. Participants visited our lab as pairs of friends and were recorded having an unscripted conversation without a researcher present. After this conversation, they each completed a series of laboratory experimental tasks and surveys. Some of the experimental tasks had to do with speech perception and production behaviors. For example, we assessed each participant's tendency to imitate features of a voice that they heard over headphones when repeating after that voice. Other experimental tasks had to do with more general traits not specific to language, such as an assessment of working memory capacity. We also included personality and cognitive style surveys as used in psychology.

To analyze this data, we transcribed the conversations and used speech processing technology to automatically extract detailed numerical measurements of a number of different vowel and consonant pronunciations known to be changing over time in the Philadelphia accent. We used statistical modeling to turn this data into numerical values representing how linguistically innovative each participant was on each of these different changing features. In other words, we could see which participants might be thought of as leaders in the advancement of each specific change. We were then in a position to ask whether the linguistic leaders we identified had a particular personality or cognitive profile as determined by the battery of experimental tasks and surveys.

One of our discoveries was that the different pronunciation changes that are taking place in Philadelphia are not all led by the same people. We can't actually pick out individuals who are linguistically innovative across the board -- only individuals who are innovative in specific linguistic features. This is not what we would expect if general personality or cognitive traits were the main factors driving how much each individual participates in ongoing language changes, because we would expect those traits to apply to all changes and therefore generate individuals who are innovative in every linguistic feature at the same time. 

We also discovered that there is a subset of Philadelphian vowel pronunciation features that do pattern together: the accent features that happen to be the most noticeable and commented on by nonlinguists. We were able to compare this clustering to historical data about vowel pronunciation in Philadelphia and show that these particular changes have actually co-occurred in Philadelphian speakers for over a century, forming the core of what is widely thought of as the Philadelphia accent. We suggest that these features became noticeable because they clustered together, rather than clustering together as a result of being noticeable. However, we did not find that the general cognitive and personality traits under investigation were able to predict which individual participants would be more innovative or conservative even among these high-salience changes. 

Finally, our Philadelphia-specific study was accompanied by a number of narrower experiments probing the particular speech perception and production mechanisms that are thought to play a role in gradual processes of language change over time. In these studies we failed to replicate the relationship between personality/cognitive style suggested by the previous work that had partly motivated this study. This casts further doubt on the likelihood that these traits will turn out to offer powerful explanations of how and why language changes.
